chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: Often, we wish to divide texts into categories. For example, we might want to categorize news stories by topic; or to divide sentences into questions and statements. In this tutorial, we will consider single-category text classification problems, in which:

listitem.para: There are a predefined set of categories.
Each text belongs to exactly one category.

chapter.para: Text classification is the task of chosing the most likely category for a given text.

section.title: Relationship to Other Tasks
section.para: Single-category text classification is related to a number of other categorization problems. The following list describes how single-category text classification differs from three related problems:

listitem.para: In multi-category text classification, each text can have zero or more categories.
In clustering, the set of categories is not predefined.
In tagging, we attempt to categorize each element in a sequence of texts (as opposed to text classification, where we categorize individual texts).

chapter.title: Labeled Texts
chapter.para: Each category is uniquely identified by a label. Labels are typically strings or integers. For example, if we are classifying news stories, our category labels might include 'sports', 'technology', and 'foreign affairs'.
Categorized text types are represented using the LabeledText class, which is defined by the nltk.classifier module. New LabeledTexts are created using the LabeledText constructor:
chapter.programlisting: &prompt; text = "What's your name?" &prompt; label = "question" &prompt; labeled_text = LabeledText(text, label) "What's your name?"/"question"

important.para: We may decide to change the printed representation for labeled texts; currently, it is identical to the printed representation for TaggedTypes.

chapter.para: A LabeledText's underlying text is accessed via the text member function; and its label is accessed via the label member function:
A labeled text token is a Tokens whose type is a LabeledText:
chapter.programlisting: &prompt; loc = Location(3, unit='s') @[3s] &prompt; labeled_token = Token(labeled_text, loc) "What's your name?"/"question"@[3s]

chapter.title: The Classifier Interface
chapter.para:
The nltk.classifier module defines
ClassifierI, a general interface for classifying texts. This interface is used by all single-category text classifiers. It requires that classifiers define two methods:

listitem.para: classify determines which label is most appropriate for a given text token, and returns a labeled text token with that label.
labels returns the list of category labels that are used by the classifier.

chapter.para: These two methods are illustrated in the following example:
chapter.programlisting:
&prompt; token = Token("What's your name?", loc) "What's your name?"@[3s] &prompt; my_classifier.classify(token) "What's your name?"/"question"@[3s]
&prompt; my_classifier.labels() ("statement", "imperative", "question")

section.title: Optional Methods
section.para: Classifiers are also encouraged (but not required) to define four additional methods:

listitem.para: prob takes a labeled text token, and returns the probability that the token's text belongs to the category indicated by the token's label.

distribution takes a text token, and returns a probability distribution, whose samples are labeled text tokens. This probability distribution indicates the likelihood that the text belongs to each label's category.
distribution_dictionary takes a text token, and returns a dictionary, mapping from each label to the probability that the text is a member of that label's category.

distribution_list takes a text token, and returns a list of probabilities, where the ith element of the list is the probability that the text belongs to the category indicated by classifier.labels()[i].

section.para: Each of these methods is illustrated in the following example:
section.programlisting:
&prompt; print labeled_token "What's your name?"/"question"@[3s]
# What's the probability that "What's your name?" is a question? &prompt; my_classifier.prob(labeled_token) 0.67
# What's the probability that "What's your name?" is a question, # given that it's not a statement? &prompt; prob_dist = my_classifier.distribution(token) &prompt; def not_statement(ltoken): ltoken.type().label()!='statement' &prompt; prob_dist.cond_prob(labeled_token, PredEvent(not_statement)) 0.85
# What is the probability for each category? &prompt; prob_dict = my_classifier.distribution_dictionary(token) &prompt; for label in prob_dict.keys(): &prompt2; print "P(%s) = %.2f" % (label, prob_dict[label]) P(statement) = 0.21 P(imperative) = 0.12 P(question) = 0.67
# What is the probability for each category? &prompt; zip(my_classifier.labels(), my_classifier.distribution_list(token)) [('statement', 0.21), ('imperative', 0.12), ('question', 0.67)]

chapter.title: Training Classifiers
chapter.para: Often, we have access to a corpus of classified texts. This training corpus is usually hand-classified, and we assume that most of the classifications are correct.
We can use statistical methods to build classifiers from a training corpus. Some of these statistical methods are discussed in following sections.

The nltk.classifier module defines
ClassifierTrainerI, a general interface for building classifiers from training corpora. It requires that classifiers define a single method, train, which takes a list of labeled tokens, and returns a new classifier. For example, the following code builds a new Naive Bayes classifier from a training corpus:
chapter.programlisting: &prompt; from nltk.classifier.naivebayes import NBClassifierTrainer &prompt; classifier = NBClassifierTrainer().train(labeled_tokens) <NBClassifier: 3 labels, 187 features>

chapter.title: Feature-Based Classification
chapter.para: Most text classification algorithms do not depend on the specific details of the task being performed. The same algorithms that we use to categorize documents by topic can also be used to categorize words by their part of speech, or to categorize acoustic signals according to which phoneme they represent. Features provide a standard way of encoding the information used to make classification decisions. This standard encoding abstracts away from the details of specifc tasks, allowing the same classifier algorithm to be used to solve many different problems.

Each feature specifies some aspect of a LabeledText that is relevant to deciding how likely that LabeledText is to occur. These features can be used by classification algorithms to examine how likely different labels are for a given text. A typical example of a feature is:

listitem.para: Whether a document contains the word "ball" and has the label "sports".

chapter.para: Notice that features depend on both the text and the label. This allows us to specify which aspects of a text are relevant for making decisions about which labels.
Features can be defined using feature detector functions, which map LabeledTexts to values. For example, the feature given above could be defined using the following function:
chapter.screen: f(ltext) = 1 if (("ball" in ltext.text) and (ltext.label == "sports")) 0 otherwise
chapter.para: The feature values produced by feature detector functions are usually booleans or integers; but occasionally, real-valued features are used.

caution.para: Many people use the term "feature" as we do, to refer to an aspect of a labeled text; but some people use the term to refer to the aspect's value. To avoid confusion, the following list gives explicit definitions of the terminology used by NLTK:

listitem.para: feature: An aspect of a LabeledText that is relevant to classification.
feature detector function: A function that defines a feature. Feature detector functions map LabeledTexts to feature values.
feature value: The value returned by a feature detector function for a particular LabeledText.

section.title: Boolean Features
section.para: Boolean features are features that generate boolean values. Boolean features are the simplest and the most common type of feature. Boolean feature detector functions usually have the form:
section.screen: f(ltext) = 1 if pred(ltext.text) and (ltext.label == L) 0 otherwise
section.para: for some boolean function pred and some label L. Boolean features are also called binary features.
Boolean features have a simple probablistic interpretation: we can think of them as events defined in the probability space of LabeledTexts.

section.title: Integer Features
section.para: Integer features are features that generate integer values. Integer feature detector functions usually have the form:
section.screen: f(ltext) = g(ltext.text) if ltext.label == L 0 otherwise
section.para: for some integer valued function g and some label L.
Integer features can be used to give classifiers access to more precise information about the text. A typical example of an integer feature detector function is:
section.screen: f(ltext) = num_occurances("ball", ltext.text) if ltext.label == "sports" 0 otherwise

section.title: Other Feature Types
section.para: Some classifier algorithms use real-valued features, or even more exotic kinds of features. NLTK allows features values to be any immutable type; but currently, NLTK only implements classifier trainers for boolean and integer features.

section.title: Feature Detectors
section.para: The nltk.classifier.feature module defines FeatureDetectorI, a general interface for implementing feature detector functions. Feature detectors are required to define a single method, detect, which takes a labeled text, and returns a feature value.

FunctionFeatureDetector provides a simple flexible implementation of the FeatureDetectorI interface. FunctionFeatureDetectors are created from Python functions with the FunctionFeatureDetector constructor:
section.programlisting: &prompt; def ball_sports(ltext): &prompt2; return ("ball" in ltext.text()) and (ltext.label() == "sports") &prompt; fdetector = FunctionFeatureDetector(ball_sports) <FeatureDetector: ball_sports>

&prompt; document1 = "John threw the ball over the fence".split() &prompt; document1 = "Mary solved the equation".split() &prompt; fdetector.detect(LabeledText(document1, "sports")) 1 &prompt; fdetector.detect(LabeledText(document2, "sports")) 0 &prompt; fdetector.detect(LabeledText(document1, "foreign affairs")) 0

section.title: Feature Detector Lists
section.para: Feature detector lists are data structures that represent the feature detector functions for a set of features. Feature detector lists serve three important functions:

listitem.para: They provide a mechanism for grouping feature detectors together.
They associate a unique identifier with each feature detector.
They allow for efficient implementations for sets of related feature detectors.

section.para: Abstractly, a feature detector list can be thought of as a list of FeatureDetectors. The index of each feature detector in the list serves as a unique identifier for that detector's feature. This identifier is known as a feature id. The feature ids for a feature detector list with N features are 0, 1, ..., N-1.

warning.para: Feature ids uniquely identify a feature, given a feature detector list. However, they are not globally unique identifiers. Thus, a single feature might have different identifiers in different feature detector lists; and two different features might have the same feature id if they are from different feature detector lists. Care must be taken not to mix feature ids from different feature detector lists.

section.title: FeatureDetectorListI
section.para: The nltk.classifier.feature module defines FeatureDetectorListI, a general interface for implementing feature detector lists. Feature detector lists are required to implement four methods: an indexing operator; a length operator; a detect method; and an addition operator.

section.title: The indexing operator
section.para: The indexing operator allows feature detector lists to be treated as lists of FeatureDetectors:
section.programlisting:
# fdlist is a feature detector list. &prompt; print fdlist <FeatureDetectorList with 6 features>
# Print the third feature detector. &prompt; fdlist[2] <FeatureDetector: ball_sports>
# Print the feature values generated for labeled_text. &prompt; labeled_text = LabeledText(document2, "foreign affairs") &prompt; for fdetector in fdlist: &prompt2; print fdetector, fdetector.detect(labeled_text) <FeatureDetector: ball_foreign_affairs> 0 <FeatureDetector: ball_weather> 0 <FeatureDetector: ball_sports> 0 <FeatureDetector: solved_foreign_affairs> 1 <FeatureDetector: solved_weather> 0 <FeatureDetector: solved_sports> 0

section.title: The length operator
section.para: The length operator returns the number of features represented by a feature detector list:
section.programlisting: &prompt; len(fdlist) 6

section.title: The detect method
section.para: The detect method takes a labeled text, and finds the feature value for each feature detector. These values are returned in a structure called a "feature value list," which is discussed in the next section. Conceptually, the detect method is equivalant to applying each individual feature detector's detect method in parallel. The following diagram compares the use of a single feature detector to the use of a feature detector list:
section.screen:
FeatureDetectorI +------------------+ labeled text --> | feature detector | --> feature value +------------------+
FeatureDetectorListI FeatureValueListI +------------------+ +---------------+ | feature detector | --> | feature value | |------------------| |---------------| | feature detector | --> | feature value | |------------------| |---------------| labeled text --> | feature detector | --> | feature value | |------------------| |---------------| | . . . | --> | . . . | |------------------| |---------------| | feature detector | --> | feature value | +------------------+ +---------------+
section.para: The following example finds the feature values for document2 with label "foreign affairs":
section.programlisting: &prompt; fdlist.detect(LabeledText(document2, "foreign affairs")) <FeatureValueList with 6 features>

section.title: The addition operator
section.para: The addition operator can be used to combine feature detector lists.
section.programlisting:
# fdlist1 and fdlist2 are feature detector lists. &prompt; print fdlist1 <FeatureDetectorList with 6 features> &prompt; print fdlist2 <FeatureDetectorList with 72 features>
&prompt; new_fdlist = fdlist1 + fdlist2 <FeatureDetectorList with 78 features>

&prompt; print fdlist2[3] <FeatureDetector: running_weathers>
&prompt; print new_fdlist[3] <FeatureDetector: asleep_sports>

section.title: Efficiency
section.para: Although feature detector lists can be abstractly thought of as lists of FeatureDetectors, they are not usually implemented that way, for efficiency reasons.

Many of the features used for classification are closely related to each other. For example, a document classifier might use features that examine whether a given word is in a document. If the feature detector list were implemented as a list of independant feature detectors, then we would need to apply each feature detector separately. This would require scanning through the document once for each word we are interested in.

Instead, we can build a feature detector list that will check for all relevant words at the same time. This feature detector list makes a single pass through the document. Each time it encounters a word that we are interested in, it updates the corresponding feature value. This approach allows for significantly more efficient feature detection.

section.title: TextFunctionFDList
section.para: The nltk.classifier.feature module defines TextFunctionFDList, a flexible implementation of the FeatureDetectorListI interface. TextFunctionFDList implements feature detector lists consisting of boolean features whose detector functions have the form:
section.screen: f(ltext) = 1 if (g(ltext.text) == val) and (ltext.label == L) 0 otherwise
section.para: For a given function g, and for each function value val and label L. TextFunctionFDList gets its name from the function g, since it is a function defined over texts.

TextFunctionFDLists are created using the TextFunctionFDList constructor, which takes a function, a list of function values, and a list of labels. The new feature detector list contains one feature detector for each (val, L) pair. The following example constructs a feature detector list that checks the length of an sentence:
section.programlisting: &prompt; def length(text): return len(text) &prompt; length_range = range(0, 25) &prompt; labels = ('statement', 'imperative', 'question') &prompt; fdlist = TextFunctionFDList(length, length_range, labels) <FeatureDetectorList with 75 features>

section.title: BagOfWordsFDList
section.para: The nltk.classifier.feature module also defines BagOfWordsFDList, a feature detector list implementation which checks which words are present in a text. In particular, it implements a feature detector list containing boolean features whose detector functions have the form:
section.screen: f(ltext) = 1 if (w in ltext.text) and (ltext.label == L) 0 otherwise
section.para: For each word w and label L.

BagOfWordsFDLists are created using the BagOfWordsFDList constructor, which takes a list of relevant words and a list of labels. The new feature detector list contains one feature detector for each (w, L) pair. The following example constructs a feature detector list that checks sentences for the presence of several informative words:
section.programlisting:
&prompt; words = 'ball company chip score attack invade' 'ball company chip score attack invade' &prompt; wordlist = words.split() ['ball', 'company', 'chip', 'score', 'attack', 'invade'] &prompt; labels = ('sports', 'foreign affairs', 'technology') ('sports', 'foreign affairs', 'technology')
&prompt; fdlist = BagOfWordsFDList(wordlist, labels) <FeatureDetectorList with 18 features>

section.title: Other Feature Detector List Implementations
section.para: nltk.classifier.feature also implements the AbstractFDList class, which provides a convenient basis for building custom feature detector lists. It also serves as a base class for most of the feature value lists provided by nltk.

section.title: Feature Value Lists
section.para: Feature value lists are data structures that represent the feature values for a set of features. Feature value lists serve three important functions:

listitem.para: They provide a mechanism for grouping feature values together.
They associate a unique identifier with each feature value.
They allow for efficient encoding of sparse sets of feature values.

section.para: Abstractly, a feature value list can be thought of as a list of the feature values for a set of features. The value for the feature whose id is i is the ith element of the list.

Feature value lists are usually created with the detect method of a feature detector list. The feature ids in the feature value list correspond with the feature ids in the feature detector list that was used to create it. In other words, the ith feature detector in the feature detector list is responsible for generating the ith feature value in the feature value list. This correspondance was illustrated in the diagram used to illustrate the detect method, above.
Usually, most of the features in a FeatureValueList have the same value. For example, a sentence-type classifier might use features of the form:
section.screen: f(ltext) = 1 if (w in ltext.text) and (ltext.label == L) 0 otherwise
section.para: for each word w and each label L. If there are 3 labels, and we are interested in 1,000 words, then there are 3,000 features; but for a typical sentence, only a handful of those features will have a nonzero value.
If most of the features in a FeatureValueLists, have the same value, the FeatureValueList is said to be sparse. The common value is called the default, and is typically zero.

section.title: FeatureValueListI
section.para: The nltk.classifier.feature module defines FeatureValueListI, a general interface for implementing feature value lists. Feature value lists are required to implement four methods: an indexing operator; a length operator; an assignments method; and a default method.

section.title: The indexing operator
section.para: The indexing operator allows feature value lists to be treated as lists of feature values:
section.programlisting:
# fvlist is a feature value list. &prompt; print fvlist <FeatureValueList with 6 features>
# Print the third feature value. &prompt; fvlist[2] 0
# Print each feature value. &prompt; print [fvalue for fvalue in fvlist] [0, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0]

section.title: The length operator
section.para: The length operator returns the number of features represented by a feature value list:
section.programlisting: &prompt; len(fvlist) 6

section.xreflabel: The assignment method and the default method
section.title: The assignment method and the default method
section.para: The assignments method and the default method provide an efficient way of processing sparse feature value lists. default returns the feature value list's default value. This is typically the value for most features in the list. assignments returns a list of (feature-id, feature-value) pairs, which specifies the feature value for all of the remaining features.
default and assignments can be used together to efficiently process large sparse feature value lists. For example, the following code calculates the sum of all feature values in fvlist:
section.programlisting: &prompt; assignments = fvlist.assignments() &prompt; sum = fvlist.default() * (len(fvlist)-len(assignments)) &prompt; for (fid, fval) in assignments: &prompt2; sum += fval &prompt; print sum 7

chapter.title: Using Classifiers
chapter.para: Before we start explaining how various classifiers work, we will look at a complete example of how classifiers can be used. This should help tie together the various data structures and interfaces that have been discussed so far. The task we will look at is sentence-type classification. In particular, we wish to categorize sentences as statements, imperatives, or questions. We will use a ClassifierTrainer to build a feature-based classifier from a training corpus.

section.title: Features
section.para: The first thing we need to do is decide which aspects of a sentence are relevant to this classification task. In other words, we must decide which features to use. After examining the training corpus, we might decide that the three following kinds of information are relevant:

listitem.para: Which words are present in the sentence
The first word of the sentence
The length of the sentence

section.title: Which words are present
section.para: To check which words are present in a sentence, we can define a BagOfWordsFDList.
section.programlisting: &prompt; word_list = open('wordlist.txt').read().split() &prompt; labels = ('statement', 'question', 'imperative') &prompt; bag_of_words_fdlist = BagOfWordsFDList(word_list, labels) <FeatureDetectorList with 1800 features>
section.para: The list of words in the file wordlist.txt indicates which words we believe are relevant to this classification task.

section.title: The first word
section.para: To check what the first word of a sentence is, we can use a TextFunctionFDList.
section.programlisting: &prompt; first_word_list = open('firstwordlist.txt').read().split() &prompt; def first_word(text): return text[0] &prompt; first_word_fdlist = TextFunctionFDList(first_word, first_word_list, labels) <FeatureDetectorList with 852 features>
section.para: The list of words in the file firstwordlist.txt indicates which first words we believe are relevant to this classification task.

section.title: Sentence length
section.para: To check the length of the sentence, we can use another TextFunctionFDList.
section.programlisting: &prompt; def length(text): return len(text) &prompt; length_range = range(0, 25) &prompt; length_fdlist = TextFunctionFDList(length, length_range, labels) <FeatureDetectorList with 75 features>

section.title: Combining the Feature Lists
section.para: Finally, we can combine these three sets of feature detectors into a single feature detector list, using the addition operator:
section.programlisting: &prompt; fdlist = bag_of_words_fdlist + first_word_fdlist + length_fdlist <FeatureDetectorList with 2727 features>

section.title: Training Corpus
section.para: Next, we need to load the training corpus. Training corpera are often stored in different formats for different tasks. For this task, we have three files: statements.txt, imperatives.txt, and questions.txt. These files contain training samples for the types of sentences indicated by their filenames. Each file has one sentence per line. The following code reads these sentences, and labels them appropriately:
section.programlisting:
&prompt; tokenizer = LineTokenizer()
&prompt; statements = open('statements.txt').read() &prompt; statement_toks = tokenizer.tokenize(statements)
&prompt; imperatives = open('imperatives.txt').read() &prompt; imperative_toks = tokenizer.tokenize(imperatives)
&prompt; questions = open('questions.txt').read() &prompt; question_toks = tokenizer.tokenize(questions)
&prompt; train_toks = (label_tokens(statement_toks, 'statement') + &prompt2; label_tokens(imperative_toks, 'imperative') + &prompt2; label_tokens(question_toks, 'question'))
section.para: label_tokens is a simple helper function that takes a list of unlabeled tokens, and returns a corresponding list of labeled tokens.

section.title: Training the Classifier
section.para: Once we've constructed a feature list and a training corpus, we can train a new classifier. First, we build a ClassifierTrainer, using the feature detector list:
section.programlisting: # Naive Bayes classifier trainer &prompt; trainer = NBClassifierTrainer(fdlist) <NBClassifierTrainer: 2727 features>
section.para: Then, we use the ClassifierTrainer to train a new classifier, using the training corpus:
section.programlisting: &prompt; classifier = trainer.train(train_toks) <NBClassifier: 3 labels, 2727 features>
section.para: If we wanted to build another kind of classifier, we could simply use a different kind of ClassifierTrainer. For example, the following code uses our feature detector list and training corpus to build a new maximum entropy classifier, using a ClassifierTrainer that implements improved iterative scaling:
section.programlisting:
# Improved Iterative Scaling maxent classifier trainer &prompt; trainer = IISMaxentClassifierTrainer(fdlist) <IISMaxentClassifierTrainer: 2727 features>
&prompt; classifier = trainer.train(train_toks) <MaxentClassifier: 3 labels, 2727 features>

section.title: Classifying New Texts
section.para: Finally, we can use the classifier we built to classify new texts:
section.programlisting:
&prompt; loc = Location(3, unit='s') &prompt; test_tok = Token("Do you enjoy classification?", loc)
&prompt; classifier.classify(test_tok) "Do you enjoy classification?"/"question"@[3s]
&prompt; prob_dict = classifier.distribution_dictionary(test_tok) &prompt; for label in prob_dict.keys(): &prompt2; print "P(%s) = %.2f" % (label, prob_dict[label]) P(statement) = 0.24 P(imperative) = 0.02 P(question) = 0.74

chapter.title: Classifier Models
chapter.para: The next three sections discuss two classifier models that are implemented by nltk: the Naive Bayes classifier and the maximum entropy classifier. This discussion serves to explain the algorithms used by these classifiers; and to explore the issues that go into implementing a classifier.

chapter.title: AbstractFeatureClassifier
chapter.para: Many feature-based classification models are based on a function that estimates the likelihood of a given FeatureValueList. This likelihood indicates how probable it is that a randomly selected labeled text will produce the given FeatureValueList. These models can then classify a given text by selecting the label which maximizes the likelihood function for the text.

This general approach to classification is captured by AbstractFeatureClassifier, which is defined by the nltk.classifier.feature module. This abstract base class provides default definitions for all of the methods defined by ClassifierI.

note.para: An abstract class is a class that is only intended for use as a base class.

chapter.para: These default definitions rely on the method fvlist_likelihood, which should be defined by a subclass. This method returns a likelihood estimate for a given FeatureValueList. This likelihood should be proportional to the probability of the labeled text that generated the feature value list. In other words:

listitem.para: fvlist_likelihood(fdlist.detect(<ext;)) ≈ Z × P(<ext;)

chapter.para: Where:

listitem.para: <ext; is a labeled text.
fdlist is the FeatureDetectorList used by the classifier.
Z is a positive normalization constant that does not depend <ext;.label().

chapter.para: The reason for the requirement that Z not depend on the label used to generate fvlist will become clear when we discuss how AbstractFeatureClassifier uses fvlist_likelihood. Note that this requirement is trivially satisfied if fvlist_likelihood returns the probability of the labeled text that generated the feature value list.

note.para: We use the term "likelihood" to emphasize that this value is not actually a probability. However, we do require that the likelihood be proportional to a probability.

section.title: Algorithms
section.para: This section discusses the algorithms used by AbstractFeatureClassifier to classify texts; the next section will describe how these algorithms are implemented. Let:

listitem.para: &t; be a text.
&l; be a label.
&Lhat;(<extlt;) = fvlist_likelihood(fdlist.detect(<extlt;))

section.title: Classifying Texts
section.para: To classify an unlabeled text t, we find the label &l; that maximizes P(&l;|&t;):

listitem.para: classify(&t;) = ARGMAX&l; P(&l;|&t;)

section.para: Using Bayes Rule, we can rewrite this as:

listitem.para: classify(&t;) = ARGMAX&l; P(<extlt;) / P(&t;)

section.para: We can then use our likelihood estimate to replace P(<extlt;):

listitem.para: classify(&t;) = ARGMAX&l; (&Lhat;(<extlt;) / Z) / P(&t;)

section.para: Since P(&t;) and Z do not depend on &l;, we can simplify this equation to:

listitem.para: classify(&t;) = ARGMAX&l; &Lhat;(<extlt;)

section.para: We can then use fvlist_likelihood to solve for &t;.

section.title: Estimating Label Probabilities
section.para: We use a similar approach for estimating the probability of a label, given a text. We wish to find P(&l;|&t;). Using Bayes Rule, we can rewrite this as:
P(&t;) is equal to the sum of P(<extlt;) over all values of &l;:
We can then use our likelihood estimate to replace P(<extlt;) and P(<extlprimet;):
Since Z does not depend on &l;, we can cancel all of the Zs:
We can then use fvlist_likelihood to solve for P(&l;|&t;).

section.title: Implementation
section.para: In this section, we will examine the implementation of several of the methods implemnted by AbstractFeatureClassifier. For information about the methods not discussed here, see nltk/classifier/feature.py.

section.title: Constructing a New AbstractFeatureClassifier
section.para: The AbstractFeatureClassifier constructor takes two arguments: a FeatureDetectorList; and a list of labels. The constructor simply records its arguments for later use.

section.title: AbstractFeatureClassifier.classify()
section.para: The classify method loops through each label, looking for the label that maximizes &Lhat;(<ext;). First, it initializes a variable to hold the current maximum:
Then it loops through each label, using fvlist_likelihood to assess that label's likelihood:
Finally, it uses the maximum label to construct and return a new labeled token:
The complete listing for AbstractFeatureClassifier.classify is:

programlisting.emphasis: # Find the label that maximizes &Lhat;(LabeledText(text, label))

section.title: AbstractFeatureClassifier.distribution_list()
section.para: AbstractFeatureClassifier.distribution_list returns a list that specifies the probability for each label. Its implementation is based on the equation for P(&l;|&t;) from :
It begins by initializing variables to hold a list of &Lhat;(<ext;) values, and the the sum of these values:
It then loops through each label, updating l_list and l_sum with the likelihood value for each label:
If &Lhat;(<ext;) was zero for all labels, it calls a zero_distribution_list. By default, this method returns a uniform distribution; but it can be overridden by subclasses.
Otherwise, it estimates P(&l;|&t;) by dividing each &Lhat;(<ext;) in l_list by l_sum:
The complete listing for AbstractFeatureClassifier.distribution_list is:

chapter.title: The Naive Bayes Classifier
chapter.para: The Naive Bayes classifier implements a simple algorithm that can achieve relatively good performance on classification tasks. This algorithm can be used with any type of feature; but it is usually used with binary features.

section.title: Using NBClassifier
section.para: The nltk.classifier.naivebayes module defines NBClassifier, a text classifier based on the Naive Bayes classificaiton algorithm. NBClassifier uses probability estimates for feature value assignments to classify texts. These probability estimates are specified using a ProbDist, whose samples are FeatureValueLists.
The NBClassifier constructor takes three arguments: a FeatureDetectorList; a list of labels; and a probability distribution that provides probability estimates for feature value assignments.
section.programlisting:
# Build a probability distribution over feature value lists. # This probability distribution will be used to estimate the # probabilities of feature value assignments. &prompt; freq_dist = SimpleFreqDist() &prompt; for tok in train_toks: &prompt2; freq_dist.inc(fdlist.detect(tok.type())) &prompt; prob_dist = MLEProbDist(freq_dist)
# Build a new Naive Bayes classifier. &prompt; classifier = NBClassifier(fdlist, labels, prob_dist) <NBClassifier: 3 labels, 2727 features>
section.para: NBClassifier supports all of the methods specified by ClassifierI:
section.programlisting: &prompt; classifier.classify(token) "What's your name?"/'question' &prompt; classifier.prob(labeled_token) 0.67 &prompt; classifier.distribution(token) <ProbDist> &prompt; classifier.distribution_dictionary(token) {'statement': 0.21, 'imperative': 0.12, 'question': 0.67} &prompt; classifier.distribution_list(token) [0.21, 0.12, 0.67]

note.para: NBClassifier uses AssignmentEvents to find the probability of each feature value assignment. If the NBClassifier is to be efficient, then its probability distribution's prob() method should process AssignmentEvents efficiently. This will be discussed further in .

section.title: Algorithms
section.para: This section discusses the algorithms used by NBClassifier; the next section will describe how these algorithms are implemented. Let:

listitem.para: &fi; be the feature whose feature id is i.
&v; be a feature value lists, where &vi; is the feature value for &fi;

section.para: Using these variables, we can write the probability for a FeatureValueList &v; as:

section.title: The Naive Bayes Assumption
section.para: The Naive Bayes assumption states that each feature value assignment is probabilistically independant of all other feature value assignments. In other words:

listitem.para: P(&fi; = x, &fj; = y) = P(&fi; = x) × P(&fj; = y)
For all i ≠ j.

section.para: Although the Naive Bayes assumption is usually not strictly true, it is often approximately correct. Thus, we can use it to find a reasonable estimate for P(&v;):
NBClassifier can then solve for P(&v;) using the probability distribution it was constructed from to find probability estimates for individual feature value assignments.

Recall that if we use AbstractFeatureClassifier as a base class, then the only method we need to implement is fvlist_likelihood, which returns a likelihood estimate for a given feature value list. Clearly, we could use this estimate of P(&v;) to implement fvlist_likelihood. However, direct implementation of this estimation formula is inefficient for sparse feature value lists.

section.title: Factoring Out Default Assignments
section.para: Since most feature value lists are sparse, NBClassifier uses the following equivalant formulation, which factors out the product of probabilities for feature assignments with default values:

listitem.para: P(&v;) ≈ Z × &Lhat;(&v;)
Z = ∏ 0≤i<n P(&fi; = D)

section.para: Where D is the FeatureValueList's default value (usually 0). Note that Q only depends on the non-default features of the labeled text; thus, we can efficiently calculate its value using the assignments method.
Z is a constant, so it does depend on the label used to generate &v;. We can therefore use &Lhat; as our likelihood estimate.

important.para: There is a minor problem with the formulation of &Lhat; that is presented here: if P(&fi; = D) is 0 for any feature, then the given equation will produce divison by zero. We can avoid this problem by excluding all features where P(&fi;=D) is 0 from Z; and not dividing by P(&fi;=D) in &Lhat;. This gives the modified formula:

listitem.para: &Lhat;(&v;) = ∏{i: &vi; ≠ D and P(&fi; = D) ≠ 0} P(&fi; = &vi;) / P(&fi; = D)

section.title: Training the Naive Bayes Classifier
section.para:
The nltk.classifier.naivebayes module defines
NBClassifierTrainer, a factory class for Naive Bayes classifiers. NBClassifierTrainers are created with the NBClassifierTrainer constructor, which takes a single FeatureDetectorList:
section.programlisting: &prompt; trainer = NBClassifierTrainer(fdlist) <NBClassifierTrainer: 2727 features>

note.para: Currently, NBClassifierTrainer only supports binary features.

section.para:
NBClassifierTrainers can be used to build new NBClassifiers from lists of training tokens, using the
train method:
section.programlisting: &prompt; classifier = trainer.train(train_toks) <NBClassifier: 3 labels, 2727 features>

section.title: Implementation
section.para: NBClassifierTrainer's train method consists of four simple steps:

listitem.para: Create a new frequency distribution. This frequency distribution will form the basis for the probability distribution that the NBClassifier uses to estimate probabilities of feature value assignments.
Populate the frequency distribution with the FeatureValueLists for each of the training tokens.
Use the frequency distribution to build a probability distribution.
Use the probability distribution to build a NBClassifier.

section.para: For now, we will skip the first step, and assume that we already have an empty frequency distribution freq_dist. To implement the second step, we simply loop over the training tokens, incrementing the count for each token's feature value list:
section.programlisting: &prompt; for tok in train_toks: &prompt2; freq_dist.inc(fdlist.detect(tok.type()))
section.para: For the third step, we can use the MLEProbDist class to convert the frequency distribution into a probability distribution:
section.programlisting: &prompt; prob_dist = MLEProbDist(freq_dist)

note.para: To smooth the probability distribution distribution, we might use some statistical estimator other than MLE. To do so, we would simply use a different ProbDist, such as LaplaceProbDist. The implementation of NBClassifierTrainer in the toolkit allows you to specify which statistical estimation you would like to use, via the keyword argument estimator. See the reference documentation for NBClassifier.train for more details.

section.para: To implement the fourth step, we simply call the NBClassifier constructor:
section.programlisting: &prompt; return NBClassifier(self._fdlist, labels, probdist)
section.para: The only task remaining is to construct the frequency distribution. Although a SimpleFreqDist could be used, it would result in very poor performance; instead, NBClassifierTrainer uses a frequency distribution that is optimized for finding the probabilities of AssignmentEvents: NBClassifierFreqDist.

section.title: NBClassifierFreqDist
section.para: NBClassifierFreqDist is a relatively simple frequency distribution that's specialized for use with NBClassifier. By placing restrictions on the types of samples and events that the probability distribution supports, NBClassifierFreqDist can be made quite efficient. The restrictions that NBClassifierFreqDist employs are:

listitem.para: Samples be boolean C{FeatureValueList}s of fixed length.
The freq method only supports AssignmentEvents.
The count method only supports AssignmentEvents.
The methods samples, cond_samples, B, bins, Nr, max, cond_max, and cond_freq are not supported.

section.para: Internally, NBClassifierFreqDist keeps track of the samples for which each feature has been active (fcount[id]); and the total number of samples (N). From these values, it can calculate the number of samples that are contained in a given AssignmentEvent:

listitem.para: count(AssignmentEvent(id, 1)) = fcount[id]
count(AssignmentEvent(id, 0)) = N - fcount[id]

section.para: Similarly, it can calculate the frequency for a given AssignmentEvent:

listitem.para: freq(AssignmentEvent(id, 1)) = fcount[id]/N
freq(AssignmentEvent(id, 0)) = 1 - fcount[id]/N

section.para: NBClassifierFreqDist uses an array to store fcount. Arrays are efficient data structures for storing homogenous data; they are defined by the Numeric module. In most cases, they can be acessed like lists. The function zeros can be used to create a new array of a given length, all of whose elements are zero.

For this reason, the version of NBClassifierFreqDist implemented in nltk.classifier.naivebayes supports several additonal methods; and will likely grow to support even more methods.

chapter.title: The Maximum Entropy Classifier
chapter.para: One problem with the Naive Bayes classifier is that its performance depends on the degree to which the features are independant. But the feature sets used for classification are rarely independant; and often, we wish to use features which are highly dependant on each other. Under these circumstances, NaiveBayesClassifier tends to give poor performance. One alternative is to use a different classifier model.

The maximum entropy classifier can use mutually dependant features to reliably classify texts. This classifier is based on the idea that we should "model all that is known and assume nothing about that which is unknown." To accomplish this goal, we considers all classifiers that are "emperically consistant" with a set of training data; and chooses the classifier that maximizes entropy.

section.title: Emperical Consistancy
section.para: A classifier is emperically consistant with a set of training data if its estimate for the frequency of each feature is equal to the frequency of that feature in the training data. In other words:

listitem.para: ∑<ext; &fdilt; × Pclassifier(<ext;) = ∑<ext; &fdilt; × freqtraining(<ext;)

section.para: for all i, where:

listitem.para: Pclassifier(<ext;) is the classifier's estimated probability for <ext;.
freqtraining(<ext;) is the frequency of <ext; in the training data.

note.para: In general, the more features we use, the stronger the constraints that emperical consistancy puts on the classifier. At one extreme, if we use no features, then any classifier will be emperically consistant with any training set. At the other extreme, if we use one feature for each possible labeled text, then only one classifier will be emperically consistant with a given training set.

section.para: It seems reasonable to require our classifier to be emperically consistant with the training data. It is this requirement allows our classifier to capture the structure of the training data. However, it is not immediately obvious why we should want to choose the classifier that maximizes entropy.

section.title: The Principle of Maximum Entropy
section.para: A classifier's entropy provides a measure of how predictable that classifier's decisions are: the higher a classifier's entropy, the more randomly it behaves. For example:

listitem.para: A classifier that always categorizes texts using the same label has an entropy of zero.
A classifier that randomly classsifies texts into categories (each with equal probability) has a very high entropy.

section.para: The intuition behind maximizing entropy is that classifiers with lower entropy introduce biases that are not justified. In order to avoid these biases, we must pick the classifier with the highest entropy. This is most easily seen with an example.

Consider the task of classifying numerical expressions as distances, volumes, dates, counts, or monetary amounts. Examining our training corpus, we notice that 3/10 of the numerical expressions are distances or volumes. There are an infinite number of classifiers that are consistant with this statistic. For example, we could hypothesize the following category probabilities:

But this classifier introduces biases that are not justified by what we know about the training data. For example, we have no reason to believe that dates are signifigantly more common than counts, or that monetary amounts never occur. In contrast, the emperically consistant distribution that maximizes entropy does not introduce any such biases:

For simple examples like the one presented here, we can find the maximum entropy classifier by hand. However, for classification tasks involving many mutually dependant features, we must employ more advanced methods.

section.title: The Conditional Exponential Model
section.para: In , we said that we can find the maximum entropy classifier by considering all classifiers that are emperically consistant with the training data, and choosing the classifier that maximizes entropy. However, there are an infinite number of classifiers that are emperically consistant with the training data.
Luckily, we can show that the maximum entropy classifier will always have a specific form. In particular, the maximum entropy classifier will always estimate P(&l;|&t;) using the formula:

listitem.para: P(&l;|&t;) = 1/Z × ∏i (&wi; × &fdiltextlt;)

section.para: Where &wi; are a set of model parameters. This form is known as the conditional exponential model.
